name: Procedural World Pipeline Overview
oneLiner: Solo R&D exploration of a scalable procedural world pipeline combining Houdini-based terrain, city, and building generation with Unreal Engine validation to test data-driven workflows, iteration speed, and runtime feasibility at world scale.
bulletpoints: Designed a modular Houdini pipeline to generate large-scale landscapes using layered heightfield data driving terrain, roads, settlements, and land use.
Built parametric city-generation systems in Houdini with zoning logic, street hierarchies, and data export for real-time validation in Unreal Engine.
Implemented a data-driven building workflow where Houdini-generated lot and zoning data is consumed by custom Unreal Engine actors and editor tools.
Validated the full pipeline in Unreal Engine through walkable environments, performance testing, and iteration on scale and visual density.
Produced internal, trailer-style breakdowns to document pipeline structure, data flow, and system maturity.

deepDive.problem: Large procedural worlds require multiple interconnected generation stages—terrain, cities, and buildings—that must share structured data while remaining editable, testable, and performant when validated inside a real-time engine.
approach: Built a layered Houdini heightfield pipeline where terrain attributes, masks, and metadata drive downstream systems such as roads, settlements, and land classification.
Developed parametric city-generation networks in Houdini using zoning rules and street hierarchies, exporting structured city data for Unreal Engine ingestion.
Implemented a building pipeline where Houdini exports lot dimensions and zoning data, consumed by custom Unreal Engine actors with dedicated editor tooling.
Used modular building construction with minimal base meshes and per-face material control via custom primitive data to support interiors and exteriors efficiently.
Validated the entire pipeline inside Unreal Engine through walkable environments, performance testing, and iteration on scale, density, and visual fidelity.
